channel.title: ğŸª´ Quartz 3. on
channel.description: Recent content in ğŸª´ Quartz 3. on

item.title: Setup
item.description: Making your own Quartz Setting up Quartz requires a basic understanding of git. If you are unfamiliar, this resource is a great place to start!

item.title: Editing Content in Quartz
item.description: Editing Quartz runs on top of Hugo so all notes are written in Markdown. Folder Structure Here’s a rough overview of what’s what.

item.title: Obsidian Vault Integration
item.description: Setup Obsidian is the preferred way to use Quartz. You can either create a new Obsidian Vault or link one that your already have.

item.title: Preview Changes
item.description: If you’d like to preview what your Quartz site looks like before deploying it to the internet, the following instructions guide you through installing the proper dependencies to run it locally.

item.title: Deploying Quartz to the Web
item.description: Hosting on GitHub Pages Quartz is designed to be effortless to deploy. If you forked and cloned Quartz directly from the repository, everything should already be good to go!

item.title: Farming activities
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Farming activities Weeding Weeds can be dangerous for young plants as they can compete for soil nutrient and for sunlight.

item.title: Japanese Standard cup sizes
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Japanese Standard cup sizes [[Sencha ç…èŒ¶]] also know as sencha-wan, 80-120ml round shape white coloured porcelain. [[Gyokuro ç‰éœ²èŒ¶]] also know as Gyokurocha-wan, ~30ml round shape white coloured porcelain.

item.title: Steamed vs pan-fired teas
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Steamed vs pan-fired teas [[Steamed processed teas è’¸ã—è£½]] teas have a stronger release of flavour at the beginning. While [[Pan-fired teas é‡œç‚’ã‚ŠèŒ¶]] develop more during the later brews.

item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Yuzamashi æ¹¯å†·ã— Water cooler, used to help cool down water for high grade teas. Paired usually to a [[Shiboridashi çµã‚Šå‡ºã—]] or a [[Kyusu æ€¥é ˆ]].

item.title: Shiboridashi çµã‚Šå‡ºã—
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Shiboridashi çµã‚Šå‡ºã— Derived from [[Gaiwan]], it also has a simpler spout and filter than [[Houin]]. Often paired with a [[Yuzamashi æ¹¯å†·ã—]]

item.title: Tea evaluation
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Tea evaluation There are two main types: Auction: Usually thematic by day(Sencha, Tencha, Gyokuro…) Competition: Like in hand rolled competitions f.

item.title: Mie ä¸‰é‡
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Mie ä¸‰é‡ includes regions like: Yokkaichi Suzuka Kameyama Linan Watarai Presents more of the production in the northern area, where there are more flatlands as well.

item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Miyazaki å®®å´ includes regions like: Takachiho Gokase Kawaminami Miyakonojo Kushima Although it is neibourh with [[Kagoshima é¹¿å…å³¶]] the spread of the farms is quite diferent.

item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Japanese Black Tea å’Œç´…èŒ¶ Black tea, mostly experimental at this point, but with a new push for developing it due to the drop in price for green tea over the last years.

item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Japanese Oolong ã‚¦ãƒ¼ãƒ­ãƒ³èŒ¶ 100-150 years the production started with somewhat of a success although it stopped being produced for many year in noticeable amounts.

item.title: Kabusecha è¢«ã›ç…èŒ¶ãƒ»è¢«ã›èŒ¶
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Kabusecha è¢«ã›ç…èŒ¶ãƒ»è¢«ã›èŒ¶ High grade loose-leaf tea, made with buds and young leafs. Sahded around 2 weeks with spring and summer harvest.

item.title: Konacha ç²‰èŒ¶
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Konacha ç²‰èŒ¶ Japanese tea fanning, y-product of high-grade teas like [[Gyokuro ç‰éœ²èŒ¶]], [[Kabusecha è¢«ã›ç…èŒ¶ãƒ»è¢«ã›èŒ¶]] and [[Sencha ç…èŒ¶]] most commonly.

item.title: Kukicha èŒèŒ¶
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Kukicha èŒèŒ¶ By-product tea separated out from [[Matcha æŠ¹èŒ¶]], [[Gyokuro ç‰éœ²èŒ¶]], [[Kabusecha è¢«ã›ç…èŒ¶ãƒ»è¢«ã›èŒ¶]], [[Sencha ç…èŒ¶]] etc in spring and summer.

item.title: Okumidori ãŠãã¿ã©ã‚Š
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Okumidori ãŠãã¿ã©ã‚Š 3% of used cultivars. [[Shizuoka é™å²¡]] 1974. One of the cultivars with more [[Umami]]. Late shooter, good yield, used for [[Gyokuro ç‰éœ²èŒ¶]] and [[Tencha æŒ½ãèŒ¶ãƒ»ç¢¾èŒ¶]]

item.title: Saemidori ã•ãˆã¿ã©ã‚Š
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Saemidori ã•ãˆã¿ã©ã‚Š [[Kagoshima é¹¿å…å³¶]] 1990, presents more [[Umami]], early shooting, good yield. Very promising cultivar, also good for [[Shaded teas è¦†ä¸‹æ ½åŸ¹]].

item.title: Sayamakaori ã•ã‚„ã¾ã‹ãŠã‚Š
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Sayamakaori ã•ã‚„ã¾ã‹ãŠã‚Š 2% of used cultivars. [[Saitama åŸ¼ç‰]] 1971. Bit astringent, strong aromas, good yield, resistant to cold, used for [[Sencha ç…èŒ¶]].

item.title: Yutakamidori ã‚†ãŸã‹ã¿ã©ã‚Š
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Yutakamidori ã‚†ãŸã‹ã¿ã©ã‚Š Represents 7% of the cultivars used as of 2020, registered in [[Shizuoka é™å²¡]] in 1966. Early shooter, good yield, more astringent, weak against cold.

item.title: Zairai åœ¨æ¥ç¨®
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Zairai åœ¨æ¥ç¨® around 1% of used genetic plant material. Natural mix of plants, unpredictable shooting, resistance to cold and insects.

item.title: Kagoshima é¹¿å…å³¶
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Kagoshima é¹¿å…å³¶ Includes regions like: Chiran Ei Kirishima Oura Takabe Ariake Tanegashima Yakushima Tea is grown all around the sea line with very few mountain sides having operations as the mountains in the Kagoshima area can be very high altitude of 1700 meters in some areas.

item.title: Shizuoka é™å²¡
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Shizuoka é™å²¡ includes regions like: Fuji Honyama Shimizu Kawane Tenryu Kakegawa Makinohara Ashikubo On the sea line the land is flatter and the land is developed into large scale production.

item.title: Japan Tea Distribution
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Japan Tea Distribution The three main actors are the growers, processors and the distributors. Although not every region has the same structures we can identify three main routes of distribution.

item.title: Camellia Sinensis
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Camellia Sinensis Camellia are plants from the Theaceae family and it is a genus of flowering plant found in eastern and southeastern Asia.

item.title: Sencha vs Gyokuro
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Sencha vs Gyokuro Perhaps the most noticeable difference between [[Sencha ç…èŒ¶]] and [[Gyokuro ç‰éœ²èŒ¶]] are the shading as the [[Processing method è£½èŒ¶æ–¹æ³•]] can be quite similar at first glance.

item.title: Yabukita ã‚„ã¶ããŸ
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Yabukita ã‚„ã¶ããŸ Was the first cultivar to be bred in [[Shizuoka é™å²¡]] in 1908, although it was not registered after some time later in 1953.

item.title: Benihomare
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Benihomare original black tea [[Japanese Black Tea å’Œç´…èŒ¶]]cultivar brought from Himalayas by —-, an envoy of the shogun at the time sent with silk and green tea.

item.title: Baisao
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Baisao Was a monk living in the Edo period (1603 - 1868) between the 1675 and 1763 when he passed away un the city of Kyoto.

item.title: Bancha ç•ªèŒ¶
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Bancha ç•ªèŒ¶ Lower grade, mature leaves. Grown under sun, summer* harvest or considered as the second part of the spring harvest

item.title: Brewing factors
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Brewing factors Type of tea Temperature Part of the leave used Water type Tea quality Time Tea:water ratio Water quality Hard water clouds and masks the tea flavour.

item.title: Caffeine
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Caffeine Belongs to Methylxanthine group, is another of the compounds that form part of the defence plant system. Used to be known as Teina because they were thought to be different compounds.

item.title: Catechin
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Catechin Catechin Belongs to the polyphenol group, and it is part of the defence system of the plant. Used to be known as Tannin.

item.title: Genmaicha ç„ç±³èŒ¶
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Genmaicha ç„ç±³èŒ¶ Genmaicha is a [[Reprocessed teas å†åŠ å·¥èŒ¶]]variation of green tea that is mixed with roasted rice. The base tea leaf is usually [[Bancha ç•ªèŒ¶]] but some can be found with [[Sencha ç…èŒ¶]] as well.

item.title: Hojicha ã»ã†ã˜èŒ¶ãƒ»ç„™ã˜èŒ¶
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Hojicha ã»ã†ã˜èŒ¶ãƒ»ç„™ã˜èŒ¶ Lower grade tea, usually made from [[Bancha ç•ªèŒ¶]] that has been roasted. References [[100 Foundation Course MOC]]

item.title: L-Theanine
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± L-Theanine Theanine Also known as L-Theanine belongs to the amino acids family, can be found in Tea and some mushroom families.

item.title: Storage of tea
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Storage of tea When storing tea the most important things to consider are: Air Temperature Light Moisture Smells The affect [[L-Theanine]], [[Caffeine]], [[Catechin]], Vitamins and Chlorophyll.

item.title: Vitamin C
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Vitamin C The name is Ascorbic Acid, present in citrus, many other fruits and vegetables. Has some tart, sour taste but not to much quantity is found in tea so it is not as noticeable usually.

item.title: 100 History of the Japanese Tea
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± History of the Japanese Tea Following is what we know from Tea in Japan, how it arrived, was grown and drink, and eventually diverged from the Chinese Tea Culture onto it own.

item.title: Temperature and Infusion time relation
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Temperature and Infusion time relation Different temperatures solubilise different compounds, like caffeine for example. The time will in part allow more of them to be diffused into the brew.

item.title: Temperature and Infusion time relation
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Temperature and Infusion time relation Different temperatures solubilise different compounds, like caffeine for example. The time will in part allow more of them to be diffused into the brew.

item.title: Temperature and Infusion time relation
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Temperature and Infusion time relation Different temperatures solubilise different compounds, like caffeine for example. The time will in part allow more of them to be diffused into the brew.

item.title: Aromatic compounds
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Aromatic compounds There are more than 300 volatile compounds found in tea. Most of the compound’s effects, characteristics, and interaction with one another are not known.

item.title: Brew color æ°´è‰²
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± The brew of the tea is one of the key factors in determining the quality of the tea itself.

item.title: Green colour preservation
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Chlorophyll is the main reason for the green color in plants. When the leaves are picked and left as it is the oxidation process will shift the color from green to a brownish black color.

item.title: Harvesting method åç©«æ–¹æ³•
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± åç©« ã—ã‚…ã†ã‹ã Tea can be harvested by hand æ‰‹æ‘˜ã¿ (ã¦ã¥ã¿) or by machine æ©Ÿæ¢°æ‘˜ã¿ (ãã‹ã„ã¥ã¿). Hand harvesting æ‰‹æ‘˜ã¿ Until the Taisho Era (1912â€“26) manual hand harvesting was the main method.

item.title: Processing method è£½èŒ¶æ–¹æ³•
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± After harvesting the leaf material it is transported into the factories, were it undergoes it’s transformation into a product that can be brewed later.

item.title: cultivar å“ç¨®
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Every varietal cultivar affects the following: å“ç¨®ç‰¹è£½ ãƒ»Taste å‘³ ãƒ»Smell é¦™ã‚Š ãƒ»amount and time of harvest åç©«é‡ã¨åç©«æ™‚æœŸ Diseases and cold resistance ç—…æ°—ãƒ»ç—…æ°—ãƒ»å¯’ã•ã¸ã®æŠµæŠ—æ€§ [[Yabukita ã‚„ã¶ããŸ]] is the most cultivated one currently at 70%, the second one is [[Yutakamidori ã‚†ãŸã‹ã¿ã©ã‚Š]]] at 6%.

item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Includes compost management, triming, organic cultivation methods, etc One of the more important ones and key to the [[Shaded teas è¦†ä¸‹æ ½åŸ¹]] like [[Tencha æŒ½ãèŒ¶ãƒ»ç¢¾èŒ¶]] and [[Gyokuro ç‰éœ²èŒ¶]] cultivation is the [[Japanese tea shading techniques]].

item.title: Shaded teas è¦†ä¸‹æ ½åŸ¹
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± è¦†ä¸‹æ ½åŸ¹ Is the method of growing tea under shades to improve the flavour of the leafs using the [[Japanese tea shading techniques]].

item.title: Matcha æŠ¹èŒ¶
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Matcha is the traditional powder tea made from [[Tencha æŒ½ãèŒ¶ãƒ»ç¢¾èŒ¶]] References [[The Story of Japanese Tea]] [[Japanese Tea - A comprehensive guide]]

item.title: Tencha æŒ½ãèŒ¶ãƒ»ç¢¾èŒ¶
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Tencha is the leaf used to produce [[Matcha æŠ¹èŒ¶]], a powdered tea made from ground tea leafs, traditionally in a stone mill.

item.title: Japanese tea shading techniques
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± See also: [[Shaded teas è¦†ä¸‹æ ½åŸ¹]] Japanese tea shading techniques è¢«è¦†æ–¹æ³• Sweetness is one of the main desired flavours together with [[Umami]].

item.title: Steamed teas
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Before 1738 the production of tea was mainly [[Tencha æŒ½ãèŒ¶ãƒ»ç¢¾èŒ¶]]. Which is a steamed and dried tea for matcha production.

item.title: Sencha ç…èŒ¶
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± ç…èŒ¶ is the most common tea produce in Japan. It is generally an unshaded tea, but it can be shaded as well, known as [[Kabusecha è¢«ã›ç…èŒ¶ãƒ»è¢«ã›èŒ¶]].

item.title: Tsuyu Hikariã€€æ¢…é›¨å…‰
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Varietal resistant to pest. Original from [[Shizuoka é™å²¡]] and low in availability, only sold in the prefecture for now.

item.title: Comodity Tea & Specialty Tea
item.description: Status: ğŸŒ± Commodity is bulk tea actively traded and the price is determined by the markets. The price is usually in currency/Kg.
One of the most well know chinese green teas, also know as the imperial green Leaf composition Bud + 1-2 leaves
Morning brew - Sencha Oku-Kirishima Today I am brewing a tea that was my introduction to high-grade tea, specifically Japanese green teas.
A morning brew - Kuura Prescription Only This Sunday, I am enjoying a Sheng Pu-erh. Resin, herbal freshness and maybe a hint of pine needles welcome me after rinsing the leaves.
Japan [[000 Japanese Tea MOC]] Awabancha Kamairicha Goishicha Hoijicha China Hongcha Chen Pi Heicha Taiwan Oolong

item.title: Callouts
item.description: Callout support Quartz supports the same Admonition-callout syntax as Obsidian. This includes 12 Distinct callout types (each with several aliases) Collapsable callouts See documentation on supported types and syntax here.

item.title: Configuration
item.description: Configuration Quartz is designed to be extremely configurable. You can find the bulk of the configuration scattered throughout the repository depending on how in-depth you’d like to get.

item.title: Custom Domain
item.description: Registrar This step is only applicable if you are using a custom domain! If you are using a <YOUR-USERNAME>.github.io domain, you can skip this step.

item.title: Growing area ç”£åœ°
item.description: The growing regions concentrate in the half south part of Japan. Shizuoka and Kagoshima having the 36% and 34% of production as of 2019 and in third place Mie with a 7%.

item.title: Hosting with Docker
item.description: If you want to host Quartz on a machine without using a webpage hosting service, it may be easier to install Docker Compose and follow the instructions below than to install Quartz’s dependencies manually.

item.title: Ignoring Notes
item.description: Quartz Ignore Edit ignoreFiles in config.toml to include paths you’d like to exclude from being rendered. 1 2 3 4 5 6 .

item.title: Quartz Philosophy
item.description: â€œ[One] who works with the door open gets all kinds of interruptions, but [they] also occasionally gets clues as to what the world is and what might be important.

item.title: Search
item.description: Quartz supports two modes of searching through content. Full-text Full-text search is the default in Quartz. It produces results that exactly match the search query.

item.title: Showcase
item.description: Want to see what Quartz can do? Here are some cool community gardens :) Quartz Documentation (this site!) Jacky Zhao’s Garden Scaling Synthesis - A hypertext research notebook AWAGMI Intern Notes Shihyu’s PKM Chloe’s Garden SlRvb’s Site Course notes for Information Technology Advanced Theory Brandon Boswell’s Garden Siyang’s Courtyard Data Dictionary ğŸ§ sspaeti.

item.title: Troubleshooting and FAQ
item.description: Still having trouble? Here are a list of common questions and problems people encounter when installing Quartz. While you’re here, join our Discord :)

item.title: Updating
item.description: Haven’t updated Quartz in a while and want all the cool new optimizations? On Unix/Mac systems you can run the following command for a one-line update!

item.title: æ—¥æœ¬èŒ¶ã®ã™ã¹ã¦ãŒåˆ†ã‹ã‚‹æœ¬ MOC
item.description: MOC for the book [[æ—¥æœ¬èŒ¶ã®ã™ã¹ã¦ãŒåˆ†ã‹ã‚‹æœ¬]] Chapter 1 - Compounds [[Catechin]] [[Caffeine]] [[L-Theanine]] [[Green colour preservation]] [[Brew color æ°´è‰²]] [[Aromatic compounds]]
